Fluid Dynamics.name: Reynolds Number
Fluid Dynamics.description: Dimensionless number that predicts flow regime (laminar or turbulent).

Fluid Dynamics.name: Reynolds Number Alternative Expression
Fluid Dynamics.description: Alternative expression to calculate the Reynolds number using mass flow rate ṁ = ρV and average velocity V = vA.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Reynolds Number (Physical meaning)

variables.Re: Reynolds number; a dimensionless quantity indicating the ratio of inertial to viscous forces in a flow
variables.Inertia force: Force due to the fluid's mass and acceleration, tending to keep the fluid in motion
variables.Viscous force: Force resisting motion due to the fluid's viscosity

Fluid Dynamics.description: Reynolds number quantifies the relative importance of inertial forces compared to viscous forces in fluid flow. Low Re indicates laminar flow dominated by viscosity, while high Re indicates turbulent flow dominated by inertia.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Bernoulli's Equation
Fluid Dynamics.description: Relates pressure, velocity, and elevation in a steady incompressible flow.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Vector Differential Operator (∇)

variables.\\frac{∂}{∂_x}: Partial derivative with respect to x
variables.\\frac{∂}{∂_y}: Partial derivative with respect to y
variables.\\frac{∂}{∂_z}: Partial derivative with respect to z

Fluid Dynamics.description: The vector differential operator (∇) is used to compute gradient, divergence, and curl of scalar and vector fields in three-dimensional space.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Gradient of a scalar field (∇s)
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \nabla s = \frac{\partial s}{\partial x} \hat{i} + \frac{\partial s}{\partial y} \hat{j} + \frac{\partial s}{\partial z} \hat{k}

variables.s: Scalar field (e.g., pressure, temperature, potential energy)
variables.\\nabla s: Gradient of the scalar field; vector pointing in the direction of maximum increase of s

Fluid Dynamics.description: The gradient of a scalar field gives a vector that points in the direction of maximum increase of the scalar quantity, with magnitude equal to the rate of change along that direction.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Divergence of a vector field (∇·v)
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \nabla \cdot \vec{v} = \frac{\partial v_x}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial v_y}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial v_z}{\partial z}

variables.\\nabla ·v: Divergence of the vector field v; measures the net rate at which fluid is exiting a point per unit volume
variables.v: Vector field (e.g., velocity field of a fluid)
variables.Positive \\nabla ·v: Indicates outward flow or expansion at a point
variables.Negative \\nabla ·v: Indicates inward flow or compression at a point
variables.\\nabla ·v = 0: Indicates incompressible flow; no net gain or loss of fluid at a point

Fluid Dynamics.description: The divergence of a vector field measures the net rate of fluid leaving a point per unit volume. Positive divergence indicates fluid is spreading out, negative indicates compression, and zero indicates incompressibility.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Divergence of the gradient of a scalar (∇·∇s)

variables.\\nabla s: Gradient of the scalar field; a vector pointing in the direction of maximum increase of s
variables.\\nabla · \\nabla s: Divergence of the gradient; equals the Laplacian of s
variables.\\nabla^2: Laplacian operator; sum of the second partial derivatives of s with respect to x, y, and z
variables.\\frac{\\partial^2 s}{\\partial x^2}, \\: Second partial derivatives of s along each Cartesian coordinate

Fluid Dynamics.description: The divergence of the gradient of a scalar function s gives the Laplacian of s. It measures how s spreads out from a point, and is widely used in physics for diffusion, heat conduction, and wave propagation problems.

Fluid Dynamics.name: The Laplacian of a vector field ∇.∇v

variables.\\nabla^2: Laplacian operator, representing the sum of second partial derivatives with respect to spatial coordinates
variables.v: Vector field (velocity field in this context)

Fluid Dynamics.description: The Laplacian of a vector field is a differential operator that measures the “spatial diffusion” or how the components of the vector field spread out in space.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Velocity Gradient Tensor
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \nabla \vec{v} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial v_x}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial v_x}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial v_x}{\partial z} \\ \frac{\partial v_y}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial v_y}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial v_y}{\partial z} \\ \frac{\partial v_z}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial v_z}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial v_z}{\partial z} \end{pmatrix}
Fluid Dynamics.description: The velocity gradient tensor representing the spatial derivatives of the velocity components in a three-dimensional flow field.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Cylindrical to Rectangular Coordinates
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \begin{cases} x = r \cos\theta \\ y = r \sin\theta \\ z = z \end{cases} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{cases} r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} \\ \theta = \arctan\frac{y}{x} \\ z = z \end{cases}

variables.z: z-coordinate (same in both cylindrical and rectangular systems)
variables.r: Radial distance from the z-axis in cylindrical system
variables.\\theta: Angular coordinate (angle from x-axis in the xy-plane) in cylindrical system

Fluid Dynamics.description: Formulas to convert between cylindrical coordinates (r, θ, z) and rectangular coordinates (x, y, z) for locating a point in three-dimensional space.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Spherical to Rectangular Coordinates
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \begin{cases} x = r \sin\theta \cos\phi \\ y = r \sin\theta \sin\phi \\ z = r \cos\theta \end{cases} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{cases} r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + z^2} \\ \theta = \arccos\left( \frac{z}{r} \right) \\ \phi = \arctan\left( \frac{y}{x} \right) \end{cases}

variables.z: z-coordinate (same in both rectangular and spherical systems)
variables.r: Radial distance from the origin in spherical system
variables.\\theta: Polar angle measured from the positive z-axis
variables.\\phi: Azimuthal angle in the xy-plane measured from the positive x-axis

Fluid Dynamics.description: Formulas to convert between spherical coordinates (r, θ, φ) and rectangular coordinates (x, y, z) for locating a point in three-dimensional space.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Partial Time Derivative (Fixed Coordinate System)

variables.\\phi: Scalar or vector field (e.g., velocity, temperature) as a function of space and time
variables.\\frac{\\partial \\phi}{\\partial t}: Rate of change of the field at a fixed point in space

Fluid Dynamics.description: Represents the rate of change of a field φ at a fixed point in space, commonly used in a coordinate system that does not move with the fluid.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Substantial Time Derivative (Coordinate System Following the Motion)

variables.\\phi: Scalar or vector field (e.g., velocity, temperature) as a function of space and time
variables.\\frac{D\\phi}{Dt}: Substantial (or material) derivative; rate of change following a fluid particle
variables.\\frac{∂\\phi}{∂t}: Local rate of change at a fixed point
variables.v · \\nabla \\phi: Convective rate of change due to motion of the fluid

Fluid Dynamics.description: Measures the total rate of change of a field φ experienced by a fluid particle moving along with the flow. It combines local and convective changes.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Total Time Derivative (Free-Moving Coordinate System)

variables.\\phi: Scalar or vector field (e.g., velocity, temperature) as a function of space and time
variables.\\frac{d_x}{d_t}, \\frac{d_y}{d_t}, \\fr: Velocity components of the moving point in x, y, z directions
variables.\\frac{d\\phi}{dt}: Total rate of change of φ as observed from a point moving along a trajectory
variables.\\frac{∂\\phi}{∂t}, \\frac{∂\\phi}{∂x},: Local rates of change with respect to time and space

Fluid Dynamics.description: Represents the rate of change of a field φ measured by an observer moving along an arbitrary trajectory. It generalizes the material derivative to any moving coordinate system.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Line Integral

variables.\\vec{B}: Vector field through which the line integral is evaluated
variables.C: Curve or path along which the integral is taken
variables.d\\vec{l}: Infinitesimal displacement vector along the curve
variables.\\int_C \\vec{B} \\cdot d\\vec{l}: Sum of the projection of F along each infinitesimal segment of the curve

Fluid Dynamics.description: The line integral measures the total effect of a vector field along a curve, such as work done by a force along a path.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Surface Integral

variables.\\vec{B}: Vector field defined over the surface S
variables.S: Surface over which the integral is evaluated
variables.d\\vec{S}: Infinitesimal area vector on the surface, pointing normal to the surface
variables.\\iint_S \\vec{B} \\cdot d\\vec{S}: Sum of the flux of F through each infinitesimal area of the surface

Fluid Dynamics.description: The surface integral measures the total flux of a vector field passing through a surface, commonly used to calculate quantities like fluid flow or electric flux.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Phenomenological Equations (Rate Equations)

variables.Rate of transport: The quantity being transported per unit time (e.g., heat, mass, momentum)
variables.Driving force: The gradient or difference that causes transport (e.g., temperature gradient, concentration difference, pressure difference)
variables.Resistance: Opposition to transport; a property of the medium or system
variables.Coefficient: Proportionality constant relating the driving force to the rate of transport (e.g., thermal conductivity, diffusion coefficient, viscosity)

Fluid Dynamics.description: Phenomenological equations relate the rate of transport of a quantity to the driving force causing it. They are the rate–driving force relationships used to write balance equations, with coefficients determined experimentally.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Newton's Law of Viscosity

variables.\\tau_{yx}: Shear stress acting on the fluid surface of constant y in the x-direction (Pa)
variables.\\mu: Dynamic viscosity of the fluid (Pa·s = kg/m.s)
variables.\\frac{dv_x}{dy}: Velocity gradient perpendicular to the direction of flow (rate of change of velocity with respect to y)
variables.v_x: Velocity of the fluid in the flow direction (x-direction) (m/s)
variables.y: Coordinate perpendicular to the flow direction

Fluid Dynamics.description: Newton's Law of Viscosity states that the shear stress in a fluid is proportional to the velocity gradient perpendicular to the flow. The constant of proportionality is the dynamic viscosity μ.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Kinematic Viscosity

variables.\\mu: Dynamic viscosity of the fluid (Pa·s or N·s/m²)

Fluid Dynamics.description: Kinematic viscosity is the ratio of a fluid's dynamic viscosity to its density. It measures the fluid's resistance to flow under the influence of gravity or other body forces.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Bingham Plastic Model

variables.τ_o: Yield stress (initial stress needed for flow to start)
variables.k_p: Constant ratio that exists between change in shear stress and change in shear rate (analogous to the viscosity of a Newtonian fluid)

Fluid Dynamics.description: The Bingham plastic model describes the relationship between shear stress and shear rate, requiring a yield stress to initiate flow.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Power Law for Pseudoplastic and Dilatant Fluids
Fluid Dynamics.description: The Power Law describes the relationship between shear stress and shear rate for pseudoplastic and dilatant fluids, where the fluid behavior depends on the value of n.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Pseudoplastic Fluids
Fluid Dynamics.description: Pseudoplastic fluids exhibit the most common type of non-Newtonian behaviour, with a flow behaviour index less than 1. The apparent viscosity decreases with increasing shear rate, showing shear thinning, and the slope of the flow curve often approaches unity at very high shear rates, making the fluid behave more Newtonian.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Dilatant Fluids
Fluid Dynamics.description: Dilatant fluids exhibit rheological behaviour opposite to that of pseudoplastics. They are uncommon, with a flow behaviour index greater than 1, and their apparent viscosity increases with shear rate.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Reynolds' Transport Theorem

variables.\\frac{\\partial N}{\\partial t}: Local time derivative of N in the control volume
variables.\\iint_{C.S.}: Surface integral over the control surface

Fluid Dynamics.description: Reynolds' transport theorem states that the rate at which the property N increases with time within the system is equal to the time rate of increase of N in the control volume plus the net rate of flow of N through the control surface.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Average Fluid Velocity

variables.v_{avg}: Average fluid velocity or bulk velocity

Fluid Dynamics.description: The average fluid velocity (v_avg) or bulk velocity is defined as the integral of the velocity vector over the cross-sectional area divided by the total area.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Overall Mass Balance Equation

variables.Input: Mass entering the system per unit time
variables.Output: Mass leaving the system per unit time
variables.Generation: Mass generated within the system per unit time (e.g., by chemical reactions)
variables.Consumption: Mass consumed within the system per unit time (e.g., by reactions or sinks)
variables.Accumulation: Rate of change of mass stored in the system per unit time

Fluid Dynamics.description: The overall mass balance equation expresses the conservation of mass for a system. It states that the net change of mass in the system equals the mass entering minus the mass leaving, plus any mass generated or minus any mass consumed within the system.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Differential Form of Overall Mass Balance (Control Volume)

variables._{CV}: Control volume, the fixed region of space under consideration
variables._{CS}: Control surface, the boundary of the control volume
variables.dV: Infinitesimal volume element within the control volume
variables.d\\vec{A}: Infinitesimal area vector on the control surface, pointing outward
variables.\\frac{d}{dt} \\int_{CV} \\rho \\, dV: Rate of change of mass within the control volume
variables.\\int_{CS} \\rho \\, \\vec{v} \\cdot d\\: Net mass flux leaving or entering the control volume
variables.ṁ_{gen}: Mass generated inside the control volume per unit time
variables.ṁ_{cons}: Mass consumed inside the control volume per unit time

Fluid Dynamics.description: The differential form of the mass balance equation for a control volume states that the rate of change of mass inside the control volume plus the net mass flux across its boundaries equals the mass generated minus the mass consumed within the volume.

Fluid Dynamics.name: The General Form of the Overall Mass Balance for a Control Volume

variables.CS: Control surface, the boundary of the control volume
variables.CV: Control volume, the fixed region of space under consideration
variables.v: Magnitude of the fluid velocity at the control surface (m/s)
variables.\\alpha: Angle between the velocity vector and the outward normal to the control surface
variables.dA: Infinitesimal area element on the control surface, pointing outward
variables.dV: Infinitesimal volume element inside the control volume
variables.\\iint_{C.S.} \\rho v \\cos\\alpha \\, d: Net mass flux through the control surface
variables.\\frac{\\partial }{\\partial t} \\iiint_: Rate of change of mass within the control volume

Fluid Dynamics.description: This equation expresses the general mass balance for a control volume: the sum of net mass flux through the control surface and the rate of accumulation of mass inside the volume is zero. It is a statement of the conservation of mass for any arbitrary control volume.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Mass Balance Equation

variables.ṁ: Mass flow rate (mass velocity or mass flux)

Fluid Dynamics.description: This is the overall mass balance equation. Physically, ρV represents the amount of mass flowing through a unit cross-sectional area per unit time.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Equation of Continuity

variables.\\frac{∂ρ}{∂t}: Local rate of change of density with time at a point
variables.∇ · (\\rho v): Divergence of mass flux; represents net mass flow out of a point

Fluid Dynamics.description: The equation of continuity expresses the principle of conservation of mass in fluid flow. It states that the rate of change of mass in a volume plus the net mass flux leaving the volume is zero. For incompressible fluids, it simplifies to ∇ · v = 0.

Fluid Dynamics.name: General Energy Equation (Extended Bernoulli Equation)

variables.\\alpha: Kinetic energy correction factor (dimensionless, usually ~1 for uniform flow)
variables.Q: Heat added to the fluid per unit mass (J/kg)
variables.W_s: Shaft work done by the fluid per unit mass (J/kg)

Fluid Dynamics.description: The general energy equation accounts for changes in enthalpy, kinetic energy, and potential energy of a fluid between two points, including heat addition and work done by or on the fluid. It is an extension of the Bernoulli equation for real fluids with energy transfer.

Fluid Dynamics.name: General Energy Equation with Shaft Work and Enthalpy Change
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \dot{W}_s = \dot{m} W_s, \quad \delta h = h_2 - h_1 = \int_{T_1}^{T_2} C_p \, dT \approx C_p \delta T

variables.Ẇ_s: Shaft work done by the fluid per unit time (W)
variables.ṁ: Mass flow rate of the fluid (kg/s)
variables.{\\delta h}: Change in specific enthalpy of the fluid (J/kg)

Fluid Dynamics.description: This form of the general energy equation relates the shaft work done by a fluid to its change in enthalpy. The enthalpy change can be calculated by integrating the specific heat over the temperature difference, or approximated as C_p times the temperature difference for small changes.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Bernoulli Equation
Fluid Dynamics.description: The Bernoulli equation states that for an incompressible, frictionless fluid along a streamline, the sum of kinetic energy per unit mass, potential energy per unit mass, and flow work per unit mass is constant.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Assumptions of the Bernoulli Equation

variables.Steady-state: Flow properties do not change with time (∂/∂t = 0)
variables.Ideal fluid: No viscosity (μ = 0); no momentum transport to walls
variables.No shaft work: No work added or extracted from the fluid (W_s = 0)
variables.\\alpha: Kinetic energy correction factor; α = 1 for uniform or turbulent flow
variables.Streamline: Bernoulli equation applies along a streamline; can also be used for a streamtube with correction factors

Fluid Dynamics.description: The Bernoulli equation assumes steady, incompressible, and frictionless (ideal) flow, with no heat transfer or shaft work. It is primarily valid along a streamline, but can be applied to a streamtube using correction factors for kinetic energy (α) and head loss (hf).

Fluid Dynamics.name: Head Terms in Bernoulli's Equation

variables.\\frac{p}{\\rho g}: Pressure head (m), the height of a fluid column representing the pressure
variables.z: Static head or elevation head (m), the height of the fluid above a reference point
variables.\\frac{v²}{2g}: Velocity head or dynamic head (m), the height corresponding to the fluid's kinetic energy
variables.\\frac{p}{\\rho g} + z + \\frac{v²}{2g}: Total head (m), sum of pressure, elevation, and velocity heads; constant along a streamline
variables.\\frac{p}{\\rho g} + z: Piezometric head (m), sum of pressure head and elevation head

Fluid Dynamics.description: In Bernoulli's equation, each term can be expressed as a head in meters. Pressure head represents the effect of pressure, static head represents elevation, and velocity head represents kinetic energy. The total head is conserved along a streamline, while the piezometric head excludes the velocity contribution.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Mechanical Energy Balance Equation

variables.z g: Potential energy per unit mass due to elevation (J/kg)

Fluid Dynamics.description: This equation represents the mechanical energy balance, where each term accounts for pressure energy, potential energy due to elevation, kinetic energy, and friction losses. The units are expressed in J/kg, equivalent to m²/s².

Fluid Dynamics.name: Mechanical Energy Balance with Work Input
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \frac{p_2 - p_1}{\rho} + (z_2 - z_1) g + \frac{v_2^2 - v_1^2}{2 \alpha} + W_s + h_f = 0, \text{J/kg}

variables.\\frac{p_2 - p_1}{\\rho}: Change in pressure energy per unit mass (J/kg)
variables.(z_2 - z_1) g: Change in potential energy per unit mass due to elevation (J/kg)
variables.\\frac{v_2^2 - v_1^2}{2 \\alpha}: Change in kinetic energy per unit mass (J/kg), adjusted by a correction factor α

Fluid Dynamics.description: This equation balances the mechanical energy with work input and friction losses, setting the net change to zero. It includes changes in pressure, elevation, kinetic energy, work done, and friction losses, all per unit mass in J/kg.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Pump Efficiency Definition
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \eta_p = \frac{\text{useful energy (given to fluid)}}{\text{total energy (supplied to pump)}} = \frac{W_p - h_{f\,pump}}{W_p}

variables.W_p: Energy supplied to pump per unit mass of fluid, J/kg
variables.h_{f_{pump}}: Total friction loss in pump per unit mass of fluid, J/kg
variables.W_p - h_{f_{pump}}: Energy delivered to fluid by pump, J/kg

Fluid Dynamics.description: Pump efficiency is defined as the ratio of useful energy delivered to the fluid to the total energy supplied to the pump, accounting for friction losses.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Efficiency and Shaft Work Relationship

variables.η_p W_p: Useful energy delivered to fluid, J/kg
variables.W_p - h_{pump}: Energy delivered to fluid by pump, J/kg

Fluid Dynamics.description: From the efficiency definition, the relationship between pump energy, friction loss, and shaft work is derived, showing shaft work as a function of pump efficiency.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Bernoulli Equation with Pump Work and Friction
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \frac{p_1}{\rho} + z_1 g + \frac{v_1^2}{2\alpha} + \eta_p W_p = \frac{p_2}{\rho} + z_2 g + \frac{v_2^2}{2\alpha} + h_f, \text{J/kg}

variables.z g: Potential energy per unit mass due to elevation (J/kg)
variables.\\frac{v^2}{2 \\alpha}: Kinetic energy per unit mass adjusted by correction factor α (J/kg)
variables.η_p W_p: Useful pump work per unit mass (J/kg)

Fluid Dynamics.description: The Bernoulli equation is corrected to include pump work efficiency and fluid friction losses, balancing energy terms across different points.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Pitot Tube Flow Measurement

variables.C_p: Dimensionless coefficient to account for deviations, determined by calibration of the Pitot tube, between 0.98 - 1

Fluid Dynamics.description: The fluid flows into the opening on the Pitot tube at point 2, pressure builds up, and then remains constant. The static pressure is measured by the static tube (p_s = p with static pressure), while the manometer measures this small pressure rise.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Pressure Drop Relation
Fluid Dynamics.description: The pressure drop Δp is related to the Δh manometer reading, accounting for the difference in densities between the manometer fluid and the fluid being measured.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Velocity Calculation

variables.C_p: Dimensionless coefficient to account for deviations, determined by calibration of the Pitot tube, between 0.98 - 1

Fluid Dynamics.description: Since the Pitot tube measures velocity at one point only in the flow, several methods can be used to obtain the average velocity in the pipe: measure velocity at the exact center of the tube to obtain v_max and calculate v_avg, measure velocity at several known positions in the pipe cross section and use v_avg = 1/A integral (v) dA for graphical integration.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Pressure Drop and Velocity in Venturi Meter
Fluid Dynamics.description: The pressure drop between point 1 and 2 is Δp = p_1 - p_2. In a Venturi meter, the velocity is increased, and the pressure decreased, at the upstream cone (p > p_2). The pressure drop is utilized to measure the rate of flow through the instrument. The basic equation for the Venturi meter is obtained by using the Bernoulli equation for incompressible fluids between point 1 and 2. Friction is neglected and the meter is assumed to be horizontal.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Continuity Equation
Fluid Dynamics.formula: \rho v_1 A_1 = \rho v_2 A_2 \quad \Rightarrow \quad v_1 \frac{A_1}{A_2} = v_2 \quad \Rightarrow \quad v_1 \frac{D_1^2}{D_2^2} = v_2
Fluid Dynamics.description: From the overall mass balance, the continuity equation relates the velocities and areas at points 1 and 2.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Velocity Calculation with Pressure Drop
Fluid Dynamics.description: Combining these two equations and eliminating v_1 yields the relationship between velocity squared and pressure drop.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Corrected Velocity with Friction Loss (Venturi Meter)

variables.C_v: Experimental coefficient to account for small friction loss

Fluid Dynamics.description: To account for the small friction loss, an experimental coefficient C_v is introduced. The coefficient depends only on the Reynolds number: C_v ≈ 0.98 for D > 0.2 m pipes, and C_v ≈ 0.99 for D > 0.2 m pipes. However, these coefficients cannot vary and individual calibration is recommended if the manufacturer calibration is not available.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Orifice Meter Velocity Calculation

variables.v_o: Velocity of fluid through the orifice (m/s)
variables.C_o: Discharge coefficient of the orifice meter (dimensionless)

Fluid Dynamics.description: This formula calculates the velocity of a fluid passing through an orifice plate by relating the measured pressure drop across the plate to the flow velocity. The discharge coefficient (Co) corrects for non-ideal effects such as friction and flow contraction. The ratio of the orifice diameter to the pipe diameter accounts for flow area restriction. This principle is commonly applied in fluid mechanics for measuring flow rates in pipelines.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Rotameter Flow Rate Calculation

variables.Q: Volumetric flow rate of the fluid (m³/s)
variables.A: Annular flow area around the float (m²)

Fluid Dynamics.description: A rotameter is a variable area flowmeter that measures fluid flow rate by balancing the upward force of the fluid with the downward weight of a float inside a tapered tube. As flow increases, the float rises until the forces are in equilibrium. The position of the float corresponds to a specific flow rate, which can be calibrated. This formula relates the flow rate to the buoyancy and drag forces acting on the float, taking into account the fluid density and float properties.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Rate of momentum accumulation

variables.\\frac{\\partial (m\\bar{v})}{\\partial: Rate of change of total momentum with respect to time
variables.\\iiint_{C.V} \\rho \\bar{v} \\, dV: Total momentum inside the control volume (integral of momentum density over the control volume)

Fluid Dynamics.description: This equation represents the rate of momentum accumulation within a control volume. It states that the time derivative of the total momentum in the control volume is equal to the derivative of the integral of momentum density over the volume.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Overall Momentum Balance in Two Directions (x-direction)
Fluid Dynamics.formula: F_{xg} + p_1 A_1 \cos{\gamma_1} - p_2 A_2 \cos{\gamma_2} + R_x = \dot{m} v_2 \cos{\gamma_2} - \dot{m} v_1 \cos{\gamma_1}

variables.F_{xg}: Body force acting in the x-direction (e.g., gravity component) (N)
variables.\\gamma_1: Flow angle at inlet (measured from x-axis, radians or degrees)
variables.\\gamma_2: Flow angle at outlet (measured from x-axis, radians or degrees)
variables.R_x: Resultant external force in the x-direction (N)

Fluid Dynamics.description: This is the momentum balance equation in the x-direction for a control volume with inlet and outlet flows. The left-hand side accounts for external forces (body forces, pressure forces, and reaction forces), while the right-hand side represents the net momentum flux across the control surfaces. A similar expression can be derived in the y-direction by replacing cosine with sine components.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Overall Momentum Balance in Two Directions (y-direction)
Fluid Dynamics.formula: R_y = \dot{m} v_2 \sin{\gamma_2} - \dot{m} v_1 \sin{\gamma_1} + p_2 A_2 \sin{\gamma_2} - p_1 A_1 \sin{\gamma_1} + mg

variables.R_y: Resultant external force in the y-direction (N)
variables.\\gamma_1: Flow angle at inlet (measured from x-axis, radians or degrees)
variables.\\gamma_2: Flow angle at outlet (measured from x-axis, radians or degrees)
variables.mg: Body force due to gravity in the y-direction (N)

Fluid Dynamics.description: This is the momentum balance equation in the y-direction for a control volume with inlet and outlet flows. The terms include the net momentum flux (mass flow rate times velocity components), pressure forces resolved along the y-axis, and the gravitational body force. Together, they balance with the resultant external force in the y-direction.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Hagen–Poiseuille Equation
Fluid Dynamics.description: The Hagen–Poiseuille equation describes the volumetric flow rate of an incompressible, laminar, Newtonian fluid through a cylindrical pipe under steady flow. It shows that the flow rate is proportional to the pressure drop and the fourth power of the pipe radius, and inversely proportional to the viscosity and length of the pipe.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Darcy–Weisbach Equation
Fluid Dynamics.description: The Darcy–Weisbach equation relates the head loss due to friction in a pipe to the length of the pipe, its diameter, the velocity of the fluid, and the friction factor. It is widely used in fluid mechanics to estimate energy losses in pipe systems.

Fluid Dynamics.name: Net Positive Suction Head (NPSH)

variables.v_s: Velocity of the fluid at pump suction (m/s)
variables.h_f: Head loss due to friction in the suction line (m)

Fluid Dynamics.description: NPSH is the difference between the pressure head at the pump suction and the vapor pressure head of the liquid. It indicates how close the fluid at the suction side is to vaporization, which is critical to avoid cavitation in pumps.
